utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Mark? Mark! Mark, please ask your father if he wants a burger. I know, you're defending the free world, please ask your dad if he wants a burger.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Dad? Dad? Mom wants to know if you want a burger.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Mom, I don't know what he wants, you ask him.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: You want a burger?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The guy drove his wheelchair into a pool, House would love that!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He'll be bored. It's a great visual but it's diagnostically boring. What about post-hair transplant aphasia guy?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Infection throwing clots, House will shoot it down and call you an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, well we wouldn't want that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What about yoga girl?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Has a good hook.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Should we lead with it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: His first day back, might want to flex his sarcasm muscle; maybe we open with one of the weaker pitches.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You ran here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's just... 8 miles.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why did you...?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why does a dog lick its – workplace acceptable euphemism for testicles?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because he can.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What have you got for me boss?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I thought you said you needed 8 weeks of rehab. You should have been back here—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I'd come back sooner, I'd only be able to run 6 miles. I never would have made it in. What have you got for me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're completely pain free? The ketamine treatment can wear off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s been 2 months. It's not wearing off. What have you got for me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It can take as long as--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are we having this discussion? Want to hear me thank you again? Thank you Dr Cuddy. Not just for removing the bullet, but thank you for putting me in a ketamine-induced coma and changing my life. Happy? I am.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Middle-aged man: had hair transplant about 2 months ago--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Infection throwing clots, you're an idiot. Except you're not an idiot, and she's holding a file for a 26-yr-old female, what have you really got for me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Girl was doing an inverted yoga pose, neck snapped, paralyzed from the neck down except the x-rays show no evidence of spinal injury. And she's cute.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, well played sir! What about Stephen Hawking trying to do the 500 butterfly?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Forget it - brain cancer, brain surgery - there's nothing left to diagnose. I would take the other one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm... I'll take them both.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You don't think he had brain cancer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course he had brain cancer; even oncologists don't screw up for 8 years.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So if there's no diagnostic issue why are you taking the case?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Treatment can be interesting.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Not to you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I've changed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, you haven't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I haven't.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Then why are you taking the case?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guy tried to kill himself.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The guy had cancer, he's a lump; he hasn't been able to touch his wife, speak to his kids.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's been in that chair for 8 years, his muscles have atrophied. Maybe I can help him with the pain. Isn't that enough of a reason to want to help?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Not for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I've changed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No you haven't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then why am I taking this case?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let's start with the cute paraplegic.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Welcome back!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You look...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Healthy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Quad with no broken neck, struck me as odd.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Uhh... you could take a whole 2 minutes to ease into being back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Taken a whole month to ease back, 8 weeks is the maximum rehab time for a gunshot wound to the stomach and neck. So, go.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We heard they never found the guy. There's no new leads?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What? You think he might have shot this patient too? Would explain her symptoms…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Could be MS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See? It's not so difficult.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's not MS. She had no symptoms before she climbed on to her head. Unless she's been upside-down for the last 10 years, MS ain't it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be transverse myelitis, swelling in the disk choking off nerve function.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: MRI's negative for that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The leg looks fine. You totally pain free?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When did this turn into 'what did you do over your summer vacation'?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's a little weird to discuss the case while you're staring at your blood on the floor.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I asked Cuddy to replace the carpet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I like the carpet. What did you do over the summer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Re-do the tests. Let's see if the source of the problem is in the limbs or the spine. Do an EMG. Whoa, whoa, whoa! Got a whole other quad to cover; this guy's still got fluid in his lungs.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You don't think that's from the pool he drank?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Give him an O2 mask. His leg muscles have atrophied, tendons have shortened from disuse causing intense pain. Tendon surgery will make him more comfortable.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Comfortable?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Scoot.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Thanks for being here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not a problem.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: My dad wouldn't kill himself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You haven't spoken to him in over 6 years.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: I know my dad.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Mark, the doctor's just trying to--

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: He wouldn't kill himself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. I'm wrong. You obviously have a better understanding of this man who drools in front of your TV set 24 hours a day.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Dr. House...

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Look, he must have been confused. It must have been an accident.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hope it was a suicide attempt. If he was trying to kill himself then he knows how miserable his life is, means there's still something there to kill; means your dad's still there.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sorry, need you.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We were doing the EMG but we never got past the insertion of the conduction pin. Did she just say thank you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I loaned her some money. What went wrong?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Nothing went wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing went wrong then something went right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You're not going to tell me why she thanked you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're not going to tell me what went right?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You did something for which she is grateful and you're... embarrassed?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: For you. Saw you coming up, thought you were a 14-yr-old boy, I set her straight.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm not telling you what went wrong - or right, until you tell me why she said thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ohhh, you got me. You know I need to know, I'm so going to fold. Except you're forgetting, there's one thing I can do now.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's either that or a reflex response.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ok, this is Dr. House. House, this is Caren--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pleasure's all mine, what happened?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: When we inserted the conduction pin, she flinched.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She flinched! Did you hear?

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: Does that mean I'm getting better?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How big is a flinch? Bigger than a twitch? Smaller than a spasm? You smoke?

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: Socially, a lot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You do yoga and you smoke?

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: I know it's hypocritical but--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not at all, the world sees your legs, no one's checking out your lungs.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How would smoking cause--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It wouldn't, just needed a lighter.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: My god!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The case was looking so promising.

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: Hey, I'm not faking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You moved, therefore you can move. Get this lunatic out of here before she bores again.

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: I'm not faking!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I heard you were watching surgery with a patient's family. Talking to a patient's family. It’s because of your hallucination, isn't it? After you were shot? You chose life; you decided you wanted meaning, so you took a case with no mystery. Something any doctor could do. A case with no upside except the satisfaction of helping another human being.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She thanked me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And... you felt nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wasn't even sure what I was supposed to feel.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's like your leg, its atrophied. Keep working it, the feeling will come.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sorry, need you, again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Told you to get rid of her.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's a good thing we didn't. Tightness in her chest, she can't breathe, it could be pleural effusion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. Either that or she's holding her breath like a 4-yr-old.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax. I'm not going to burn you again. I'm going to STAB YOU! Look, either you're faking, or you've got a pleural effusion - that's a build-up of fluid around the lungs which is very serious - and I would have no choice but to stab you in the back with this needle and suck all the fluid out of you. So--

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We should give her a local.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That would defeat the point of me being nasty. Ready? Down.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But she can't breathe if she's down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Down!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She can't breathe--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Down! Down, down, down! Come on!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That's not a pleural effusion.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Problem's in her heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can't fake that.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Had to relieve the pressure 3 times in the last 2 hours. So either we figure out what's causing blood to build up around her heart or I follow her around with the needle for the rest of her life.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Echo was clean, no structural abnormalities.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be an infectious process. TB?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Or vasculitis would also explain the effusion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But not the paralysis. Let's assume that she wasn't faking it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She moved, therefore she could move. She wasn't paralyzed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ehh... doesn't mean she was faking, could have been a delusion. Now, either she was faking, and coincidentally got a real cardiac problem at the exact same time, or it's a delusion and the fake paralysis is a real neurological symptom.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're thinking vascular tumor on her spine?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her platelets are normal.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And she's been scanned up and down, it's all clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, open her up, and find it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So what do you want us to do? Start at her neck and just keep cutting down her spine until we stumble on something?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That should work.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His heart rate's a little high.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Should I be worried?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Probably just means he's still in discomfort from the surgery. I'm going to up his morphine a little.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: You've been so nice to us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's the job.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: No, I mean all the other doctors, all they did was obsess on the... the cancer, the treatment, the damage... just trying to fix him. You're the first doctor that's ever given a damn about the quality of his life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His heart rate's come down, the morphine worked I was right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What a touching moment. That's why we become doctors. For those rare moments when our hearts are warm--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Would you like to get a drink?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Are you serious or are you just trying to change the subject?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I'm serious. I drink, you drink. We could do it at the same time, same table. Do you eat? We could do that too. I mean, if the answer's no that's cool but...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, I... it's just... you're just coming off the surgery and you're not yourself yet and I work for you and even though last year's... you're smiling! I'm saying no and you're smiling!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, don't take it personally. Its just coz you're full of crap. You have no interest in going out with me. Maybe you did, when I couldn't walk and I was a sick puppy that you could nurture back to health. Now that I'm healthy, there's nothing in it for you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You are not healthy. Cuddy wants to see you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You've been back at work 24 hours and you're already playing hide and seek in a woman's spine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who won the pool?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There's no tumor. Her platelets are normal, scans--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's the worst that can happen? I paralyze her. She won't even notice.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Her lawyers might. You're not doing the surgery. And lower the morphine on your other patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine, I'll lower it. If you'll let me do the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What? You want a trade? We're not swapping a couple of goats for your help putting up a barn.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want something, I want something. We compromise. It's the grown-up way to resolve our differences.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There already is a mechanism for that. It's called the employer-employee relationship. I get what I want, and you don't.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You tried to swap?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ran a few more tests, came back negative, surgery's on.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You really don't give a crap, do you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does that make me evil?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The girl's life is at stake, what we're talking about with the guy--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What we're talking about is the reason you took the case; to help someone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too bad for them.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Too bad for you. The reason we crave meaning is because it makes us happy. The first level of happiness is--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm not going away.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The fifth level of happiness involves creation. Changing lives.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sixth level is heroin; seventh level is you going away.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're saving lives, which is tantamount to creating lives but all you're taking away from this, is the game. You don't have to listen to them thanking you, you don't have to change the cases you take or even how you handle them. You just have to know that you made a difference.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: House, you're not--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm not an idiot. Move.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: House, leave her alone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Close her up, you wanna know why?

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: The room's no longer sterile.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True, it's not the most interesting reason. That is not a sexy big toe. You'd never put that in your mouth.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: What the hell has that got to do with--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Told you it was interesting; it gets even better.

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: Scurvy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah. Drink.

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: Like what sailors get when they don't eat right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Aye, aye. Your arms and leg tissues are choked with blood. Makes it hard to move. Also damages your hair and toenails.

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: But I'm on this great diet, lots of protein, lots of--

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No vitamin C. Now drink.

utterance.speaker: Caren
utterance.content: Well... thank you. And thank Dr House.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Send him a note.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: The uh... nurse changed his morphine, I thought you were worried about--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's just post-op discomfort. He's ready to go home.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: So he won't have any pain?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eventually.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everything else will be the same.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Well, you took away his pain and that, that changes a lot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why don't you put him in some sort of... facility? Some place without a pool.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Yeah. I could dump him there, except he's my husband. He's my son's father.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. Kids need a dad; someone to play catch with. Talk about girls.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Mark's learned that you don't have to abandon someone just because--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get a dog.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I'm taking care of him for the same reason you helped us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Some guy shot you and you hallucinated?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I have a responsibility.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So he's just an anchor weighing you and your family down, sapping your energy, wasting your life - that's the meaning you take from this?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I want to take care of him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You enjoy this?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I can't abandon him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So you don't want to take care of him. Taking care of him doesn't fulfill you, make you happy. But not taking care of him would make you miserable.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Okay, here we go.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I don't need your help, I've done this a million times.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Here, let me...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do that again, make that sound.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: What was that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That... was talking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You guys are lousy doctors. You're in such a rush to make the patient feel better you forgot to check what was wrong.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yoga girl walked out of here 2 hours ago, you fixed her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not her, the other guy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He had brain cancer; they removed it 8 years ago. His condition's been the same ever since.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Until last night, he spoke.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What'd he say?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guhhhhhhh.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He grunted?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You want us to dissect 8 years of medical history with grunting in the differential?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sounds good. Call me when you're done.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're fabricating a mystery because you're bored.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am not bored. Damn it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You didn't tell the wife it was only a grunt?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course not, because then she would never have consented to a bunch of dangerous tests. I don't remember you being this bitchy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The Vicodin dulled it, in the sober light of day I'm a buzz kill. You're giving false hope to a family that’s been wrecked. Don't torture them, let it go, tell the wife it was only a grunt, tell her to go home.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can't let her down like that, pumped her up with too much false hope. Oh! I stuck that primo! How rad am I?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: 2002, patient had dry eyes.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Dry eyes plus a grunt, it all makes sense.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He had neurological issues.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I get hay fever, I put drops in my eyes, I don't go to a neurologist.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dry eyes could indicate an autonomic dysfunction; goes on the board.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What about coughing or boogers. Should we include boogers?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm happy we're doing this, I'd much rather do this than lengthen some guy's tendon. Patient's headaches increased. Doc scanned his head, found a tumor.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You like wasting your time?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm learning.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: To do what? Reconsider solved cases because you don't want to deal with the real world? He's pushing when there's nothing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cameron, you are an excellent doctor, you'll get lots of tearful thank yous from grateful patients.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, am I such a bitch for wanting that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, it's not a bad thing, but it's not why I'm here. I took this fellowship to learn from House.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's teaching you to be a masochist.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Dry eyes, goes on the board.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: In 8 years the patient experienced 214 symptoms, many of them repeating.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any patterns?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fever plus frequent urination could mean prostatitis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or a urinary tract infection.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: White count was normal, no infection.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If you add pain into the mix, fever, frequent urination could indicate a kidney problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I like it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, creatinine and BUN were both normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not the kidney part, the pain part. Abdominal pain plus all that stuff could equal a pancreatic cyst.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Perfect, you managed to pick the one symptom he never had. Abdominal pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's the first symptom on the board. Grunt.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Grunting isn't pathognomonic for abdominal pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, traditional diagnostic marker is compression of the diaphragm, vibration of the larynx leading to the audible sound 'I have a pain in my abdomen'.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Richard's symptoms are culled from 8 years of medical history. They're not patterned. These are random individual events over time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Illnesses have incubation periods. Do an upper endoscopic ultrasound.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His throat will collapse, muscle degeneration in his neck won't tolerate the scope, it's an automatic trach!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're talking about him like he's an invalid.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, we're insensitive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does he drool? Can he hold his neck straight? Does he choke on his food? His neck's fine, his throat's not going to collapse. Cameron, get consent from the wife.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Open. I need you to swallow. Sorry about that. Here we go. Passing through the lower esophageal sphincter into the atrium of the stomach. There's the tail of the pancreas.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Looks clean.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Moving medially, the body and the head of the pancreas look clean.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Get it out, get it out!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's stuck, I can't move it. His throat’s collapsed.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Vitals all over the place. We're losing him.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cutting.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We trached him, endoscopically removed the probe and he's breathing again. So, all in all, great idea.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get a look at the pancreas before the world ended?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It was clean.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Which means barring anything else, meaning you, he can go home tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This man nearly died. How can you discharge him?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His throat collapsed because of what we predicted.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You stick something down someone's throat, they gag, spasm, which he did. It took us a half an hour to get that thing out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Except that our patient's throat was sedated. Which means the brain should have sent a signal not to do anything. This could be cancer, or some bizarre neuro-degeneration, even a new type of vasculitis--

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Stop it. You're enjoying this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I find it interesting.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's interesting only if you're right; if you're wrong we're torturing this guy to amuse you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Half hour to remove the probe?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's not a spasm. His throat didn't collapse, it locked down. Brain is supposed to tell every muscle in the body to relax and contract at the same time, this muscle was only contracting which means a signal from the brain was not getting through.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There are no lesions on his brain, nothing to interrupt the new orders.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All it takes is one wire down.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You have no evidence of any wires down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A few micro-tumors on the meninges, suddenly you're choking to death.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You want to look at the lining of his brain? The amount of contrast material you need to pump up there just to see it--

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He will bleed into his brain!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, he won't.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because that wouldn't be interesting. You can get permission this time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The brain is enclosed in a sac called the meninges--

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Does this mean that the cancer's back?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, no, no, no.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If we found cancer, it wouldn't be the original cancer. It'd be new.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: So what, more surgery? More radiation?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Might not be the worst thing. If this isn't just ancient history then maybe it's something we can correct. Might even get some brain function back.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: He could get better?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But understanding what you're saying would be nice. Maybe you can figure out ways to communicate.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Thank God he spoke to you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Mrs. McNeil, the test to do this is very risky. He could die.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: He's already dead.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chase, go slow.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Already injected it into his spinal canal. Next stop, his brain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Contrast material entering into the fourth ventricle. No parenchymal bleeds.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Blood pressure's high. But it's holding.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Meninges are intact, no bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, God. Foreman, get in here!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Surgeon repaired the CSF leak.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You're lucky he didn't die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm lucky? He's the one who didn't die.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We told you he'd hemorrhage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Told me he'd bleed into his brain, not out of his ear.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You've got to drop this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We're missing something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We did a dangerous test and something bad happened, that's all this is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Give me a tour of the brain, Foreman. Walk me through the scans. 1998, what happened?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: 5 cm grade 4 astrocytoma between the parietal--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing. Next, a speck on the superior temporal region.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's a regrowth, benign.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Star thingy next to the Rathke cleft.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Scar tissue from the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House every speck is not a suspect, its years of surgeons digging around in his head. Let him go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Re-do every blood test he's ever had. Re-scan his head.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. He's been sick and suffering for 8 years, I'm not going to help you make it worse; I'm not going to help you make it interesting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's ok, Foreman's better at that stuff than you are. We need 5mm cuts through the occipital and hypothalamic regions.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How many millimeters?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can help him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's it? That's your argument?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seems like a good one.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If I thought for a second you wanted to help him, you'd have carte blanche. You're doing this because it's fun.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does nobody in this hospital have anything better to talk about than my motives? My motives have nothing to do with the case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your motives have everything to do with your judgment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: For the first time in years I've got no opiates in my body, now you question my judgment.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: 24 times a year you come storming into my office spouting that you can help someone. Only you never say those words, you say something like his pancreas is going to explode because his brain is on fire! You come here with medicine, not with platitudes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn't want to bore you with the details.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There are no details, you've a hunch. House, you don't use hunches, you always have reasons. This hospital doesn't exist for your whims. I'm sorry. As of 7 am tomorrow morning, I'm sending your patient home.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The answer's no. Cuddy called 30 seconds after you left and said you'd try an end around.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My leg hurt.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How bad?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Enough that I'm telling you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did it go away?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ached for a while. First time I felt anything there since the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: But it went away?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It was muscular, it was some cramping. What are you smiling about?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're 40 something years old, you've been running God knows how many miles a day, fallen a hundred times off that skateboard and you're shocked to have some soreness?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just give me a prescription.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: For Vicodin? House, people get aching joints, cramps, they put on an ice pack, they take some ibuprofen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know what the pangs of middle age feel like.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, you don't, because you've been stuffing vicodin every 5 minutes since you turned middle age.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The surgery didn't work.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Don't play me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think this is a scam?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think you want me to feel sorry for you and either do the end around on Cuddy or give you the drugs. Either way, you get the high you think you need. House, your surgery worked, you're fine. It's just going to take time for it to feel good.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Circumventricular system sends his cytokines, releasing the early stages of the immune response but CDOS releases prostaglandins that reset the hypothalamic set point upward, unless it's countered by antipyretic therapy. So yeah, his brain's on fire. The suicide attempt was not a suicide attempt; he drove that wheelchair into the pool because he couldn't regulate his body temperature. He had hypothalamic dysregulation.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And you discovered this when you stepped into the university pool?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fountain. I can cure him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Cure him? Even if the fountain proved anything, fixing hypothalamic dysregulation isn't going to regenerate brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, but if the scar tissue on his hypothalamus is resting against the pituitary, the adrenals would shut down. Addison's disease.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You didn't see any scar tissue on his MRI, his CT scan--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His brain is functional.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: His temperature's normal. There is nothing wrong with his hypothalamus or his pituitary!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can make him walk! I can make him talk!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is a wild guess! That came to you because you were… sweating.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Inject him with cortisol. The guy will have sex with his wife again, he'll hug his kid again. Hopefully that's the combination he was using, it'd be a shame if I'd cured a pedophile. You're smiling, that's a bad sign.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're high.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I told you, I haven't had anything in 3 months.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is as high as you get. A theory that ties your case up in a neat little bow but you don't have a lick of substantiating proof.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your decision doesn't make any sense. There is no risk to a cortisol injection. If I'm wrong, big deal. He goes home a vegetable like he already is, but if I'm right--

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This isn't about downsides or risk management. It is a big deal for you to understand the word no! I'm sorry, House.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He's on his way out of here. Figure you'd be on your scooter racing down the halls to stab the patient in the neck with cortisol.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She was right to say no. I had no objective reason to think that I was right. Just needed the puzzle.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Hold on a sec.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Everything alright?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah, it's just something I forgot.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: What's that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is cortisol and it's to fight infection. Want to hold on to that? Just put a bandage on it.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Is he ok?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Can we go now?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You can go.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Richard! Richard...

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Dad, you ok?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Richard? Richard! Richard!

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Richard... you're... you're standing.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He got up. I have to go tell House.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. Cuddy, you can't tell him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I have to tell him. He was right!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why did you do it? Why did you think he might be right?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Because he's House?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Medically, what made you think he was right?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He got lucky, that's all that happened. Telling him no was a good thing because next time he won't get lucky, he'll kill someone. Just because he was right doesn't mean he wasn't wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I see him every day, I can't just...

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Everybody lies.
